rename.to: NullReferenceException when using [TestFixtureSource] in generic class

rename.from: NullReferenceException when using [TestFixtureSource] in generic class
rename.to: NullReferenceException when using [TestFixtureSource] on generic class

issue.title: Console returns 0 for invalid fixtures

milestone.description:
In the 3.4 release, we plan to improve the engine to allow it to run tests targeting platforms and .NET frameworks that are currently only supported through NUnitLite based runners. This includes platforms like .NET Core and Universal Windows. Ideally, this will also improve the way we run tests on mobile platforms like Android and iOS.

Since these features will be a part of the engine, any runners using the engine will automatically support the new platforms.

In addition, we will be fixing issues and completing enhancements in the backlog in priority order.

We are planning on maintaining a quarterly release cycle and plan on releasing 3.4 at the end of June.

body:
@ChrisMaddock It's usually best if somebody manages to actually review, categorize and prioritize an issue before we work on it. As a committer, you're able to do that yourself. It's a small thing, but it allows us all the opportunity to come back and say whether we agree or disagree with how you are suggesting to handle it. Additionally, if you then decide you want to work on the issue, please assign it to yourself, so that everybody knows.

In this case, it's probably no harm since it seems like your review and fix all came together  this morning anyway. We can all comment on the issue and the fix simultaneously. :-)
The return code issue is something I thought we had already dealt with. I'll have to search.

rename.from: NullReferenceException when using [TestFixtureSource] on generic class
rename.to: NullReferenceException when [TestFixtureSource] refers to data in a generic class.

body:
I changed the title again. The problem isn't using [TestFixtureSource] in a generic class, it's when the data referred to lives in the same or probably even a different generic class.

I'd expect this to occur if the data source were an instance member of a class implementing IEnumerable. In that case, NUnit has to create an instance of the object and would not have enough information to do so, since no Type parameter is provided anywhere.

However, your example uses static data, so I find it a bit surprising.

@CharliePoole 

> In this case, it's probably no harm since it seems like your review and fix all came together this morning anyway. 

A little confused - I haven't done any work to fix this issue? This is unrelated to #1377, if that was your thinking? Was just aiming to first create a smaller reproducible example here, apologies if I've overstepped somewhere!

> The problem isn't using [TestFixtureSource] in a generic class, it's when the data referred to lives in the same or probably even a different generic class.

In @yaakov-h's original project, it's the test fixture class which is generic, not the class where the data lives. I've inadvertently lost that distinction in my example however, by trying to oversimplify.

This is potentially tricky in that there could be some things that can never work along with others that really should be made to work. For example, if NUnit is expected to instantiate some generic class without knowing what Type parameters to use... well, that's just not gonna happen!

issue.title: Typesafe marking and general refactoring

repository.name: starling-tool
repository.description: An automatic verifier for concurrent algorithms.

body:
@yaakov-h @ChrisMaddock I looked at this further, planning to work on it, but I no longer think it's a bug, at least not as originally stated. Please review the following and comment before I go further.

TestFixtureSourceAttribute provides the arguments for instantiating a TestFixture, that is constructor arguments. The ArrayTestCase class has only a default constructor and @yaakov-h is trying to use the attribute to provide the type parameters. Unfortunately, since that's not what the attribute does, NUnit is unable to determine what type parameter to use in instantiating the class.

The repro that @ChrisMaddock wrote is slightly different. He provides a constructor taking a string argument. However, for NUnit's generic type parameter detection to come into play, we need a constructor that takes an argument of type T.

In both these examples, the simplest way to specify the type parameters is to forget about TestFixtureSoureAttribute and simply use the TypeArgs named parameter of TestFixtureAttribute. This won't solve the problem where you may need a degree of indirection in determining the types to instantiate, but that doesn't seem to be the case here.

There is at least a minimal bug here: we should be giving a better error message.

Alternatively, we could take it a step further and create a new feature whereby TestFixtureSourceAttribute allowed you to specify the type parameters directly. That may be a separate issue, however.

What do you guys think?
